w:r.w:t: (Update field to populate TOC in Word)

GradeThread is a SaaS platform that provides standardized, AI-powered condition grading for pre-owned clothing. Sellers submit structured photos of garments, and the platform returns a numerical condition grade (CG 1.0–10.0), a detailed condition report, and a shareable grade certificate. The platform addresses the massive trust gap in the $350B+ secondhand clothing market, where condition is currently self-reported with no standardization.

GradeThread will be built on the same proven stack as existing Pearson Media platforms: TypeScript React frontend with a self-hosted Supabase backend running on Contabo VPS. The platform will launch with a focused vertical (streetwear/sneakers) and expand into additional clothing categories as the AI model matures.

Every pre-owned clothing transaction on platforms like eBay, Poshmark, Mercari, Depop, and Grailed carries a fundamental trust problem: the seller describes the item’s condition with no independent verification. Terms like “Like New,” “Good Condition,” and “Gently Used” are subjective and mean different things to every seller. This results in high return rates, buyer disputes, and lost revenue for sellers.
The global secondhand apparel market is projected to exceed $350B by 2028.
Authentication services exist for luxury goods (Entrupy, CheckCheck) but focus exclusively on authenticity, not condition.
Sports cards have PSA, BGS, and emerging AI grading services (AGS). Clothing has zero equivalent.
Clothing resellers spend significant time writing condition descriptions and managing buyer complaints about condition discrepancies.
Time spent writing condition descriptions; return disputes
Fast AI grading saves time; trusted grade reduces returns by 30-50%
Uncertainty about pricing based on condition
Objective grade helps set competitive, fair pricing
Neutral third-party grade provides confidence to purchase
Standardized grading for inventory and pricing consistency
High dispute/return rates on used items
API integration for built-in condition grading on listings
— Suggested primary domain: GradeThread.com (alternatives: ThreadGrade.com, WearGrade.com)
GradeThread uses a 1.0–10.0 scale with half-point increments, inspired by the familiarity of sports card grading:
Unworn, tags attached, no defects whatsoever
Unworn or tried on once, no visible wear, tags may be removed
Minimal wear, no stains, no pilling, no structural issues
Light wear visible on close inspection, minor fading allowed
Moderate wear, light pilling, minor fading, fully functional
Visible wear, some pilling, minor stains, fully wearable
Significant wear, noticeable stains or damage, still wearable
Heavy wear, multiple defects, functional but compromised
Severe damage, holes, tears, or stains; best for craft/parts
Each garment is scored across multiple weighted factors that contribute to the final composite grade:
Pilling, thinning, holes, snags, fabric pulls
Seam integrity, zipper function, button condition, elastic stretch
Overall color fidelity, uneven fading, sun damage
Collar stretch, cuff wear, knee bagging, heel drag
Tag condition, original hardware, overall appearance
Consistent with existing Pearson Media platforms
Lightweight global state; server state caching
PostgreSQL, Auth, Storage, Edge Functions, Realtime
Edge CDN, automatic deployments from Git
OpenAI GPT-4o Vision or Claude Vision API
Per-grade fees, subscriptions, API usage billing
Following the same deployment pattern as the existing Pearson Media platforms on Contabo VPS:
Docker Compose deployment with all Supabase services (PostgreSQL, GoTrue Auth, Storage API, PostgREST, Realtime, Edge Functions)
Nginx reverse proxy with SSL via Let’s Encrypt (Certbot auto-renewal)
Automated daily backups to Cloudflare R2 using pg_dump cron job
Resource allocation: 2 vCPU / 4GB RAM minimum (scale based on image processing load)
The following outlines the primary PostgreSQL tables. All tables include standard id (UUID), created_at, and updated_at columns. Row Level Security (RLS) policies enforce data isolation per user.
Primary key linked to Supabase Auth
shirt | pants | jacket | shoes | hat | dress | other
front | back | tag | detail_1 | detail_2 | defect_1 | defect_2 | defect_3
Raw AI vision response for this image
Array of detected defects with locations
Supabase Auth with email/password, Google OAuth, and Apple OAuth
Onboarding flow: select primary use case (seller, buyer, consignment, developer)
Dashboard with submission history, grade stats, and usage tracking
The core user journey for grading a garment:
User selects garment type (shirt, pants, jacket, shoes, etc.), enters brand, and selects category (streetwear, luxury, vintage, athletic, casual).

Guided camera/upload interface requiring minimum 4 photos (front, back, tag/label, and at least one detail shot). Optional defect photos (up to 3). Each photo slot has an overlay guide showing the expected framing. Images are validated for minimum resolution (1200x1200px), proper lighting, and focus quality. Sharp processes images server-side for normalization.
User chooses Standard ($2.99, 24-hour turnaround, AI-only), Premium ($7.99, 4-hour turnaround, AI + human review), or Express ($12.99, 1-hour turnaround, AI + priority human review).
Stripe checkout. On successful payment, submission enters processing queue. User receives email confirmation with estimated completion time.
Supabase Edge Function triggers AI Vision API with structured prompt. Each image is analyzed individually, then a composite analysis synthesizes all images into factor scores and an overall grade.

User receives email notification. Dashboard shows full grade report with: overall grade + label, individual factor scores with visual breakdown, detected defects (marked on images if possible), AI confidence score, condition summary, and shareable certificate link.

Each graded item receives a unique, shareable certificate at gradethread.com/cert/{id} containing the grade, garment photos, factor breakdown, and a QR code for verification. Certificates are designed for embedding in marketplace listings. Certificate pages include Open Graph meta tags for rich previews when shared on social media.
Submission history with filtering by status, grade range, date, garment type
Grade analytics: average grades, distribution charts, trend over time
Quick-resubmit for items that failed or need regrading
Bulk submission management for power sellers
Export grades as CSV for inventory management

Users can dispute a grade within 7 days of issuance. Disputes include a text explanation and optional additional photos. Premium and Express tiers get priority dispute handling. Disputes are resolved by human reviewers with access to the original AI analysis and additional context.

RESTful API enabling marketplaces, resale tools, and third-party platforms to submit items for grading programmatically. Endpoints include submit, check status, and retrieve results. API keys with configurable rate limits and scopes. Webhook support for grade completion notifications. SDK packages for JavaScript/TypeScript and Python.
eBay: Auto-populate listing descriptions with grade and link to certificate
Poshmark: Browser extension injects grade badge into listing photos
Mercari: Grade data via API for partner integration
Depop/Grailed: Certificate URL embedding in listings

Expand the AI model to detect counterfeit indicators including stitching patterns, tag typography analysis, hardware quality markers, and material texture analysis. This becomes a separate, premium service layer on top of condition grading. Partner with authentication experts to build training datasets.
Batch upload interface for grading 10–100+ items at once with volume discounts
Consignment intake workflow with intake forms, client tracking, and pricing recommendations based on grade
Team accounts with role-based access (grader, manager, owner)
White-label certificate option for consignment stores

Track sold prices of graded items to build a dataset correlating grade to realized sale price. Surface pricing recommendations based on grade, brand, category, and market trends. This data becomes a powerful differentiator and can be monetized as a data product.

Native mobile app (React Native or Swift) optimized for camera-first submission flow. Push notifications for grade completion. Offline photo capture with background upload. Barcode/tag scanning for brand identification.

The grading engine uses a multi-image vision API (GPT-4o or Claude Vision) with a highly structured prompt that instructs the model to analyze each image against the six condition factors. The prompt enforces JSON output with specific score ranges and required fields.
Each submission triggers two API calls:

Each uploaded image is analyzed individually for defects, wear indicators, and condition signals specific to the image type (e.g., front shot focuses on overall appearance, detail shots focus on specific defects).
All per-image analyses are combined into a single composite prompt that produces the final factor scores, overall grade, defect summary, and condition narrative.

The grading prompt includes: a system role defining the AI as an expert clothing condition assessor, the grading scale definitions with examples, garment-type-specific scoring criteria (shoes are graded differently than shirts), a strict JSON output schema, and instructions to flag low-confidence assessments for human review. Prompts are versioned and A/B tested to improve accuracy over time.

The AI returns a confidence score (0.00–1.00) with each grade. Submissions with confidence below 0.75 are automatically flagged for human review regardless of tier. Premium and Express tiers always receive human review. Human reviewers can adjust the AI grade by up to 1.5 points; larger adjustments require a supervisor override. All human adjustments are logged for model retraining.
Phase 1 (MVP): Use pre-trained vision models with prompt engineering only. No fine-tuning.
Phase 2: Build labeled dataset from human-reviewed grades. Fine-tune a vision model specifically for clothing condition assessment.
Phase 3: Proprietary model trained on GradeThread’s growing dataset. This is the long-term moat.
All grades, images, human adjustments, and dispute outcomes feed into the training pipeline.
AI + human review, detailed report, certificate
AI + priority human review, detailed report, certificate
Everything + API access (100 req/min), bulk upload
White-label, dedicated support, SLA, custom integrations

API access is available on Pro and Enterprise plans. Usage-based pricing at $1.49/grade (Standard) through the API, with volume discounts at 500+ grades/month ($0.99) and 2000+ grades/month ($0.69). Webhook delivery included. SLA of 99.9% uptime on Enterprise.

Launch with streetwear (t-shirts, hoodies, sneakers) as the initial vertical. This market has highly engaged resellers, strong brand recognition that aids AI training, active communities on Reddit, Discord, and social media, and a culture already familiar with grading from sneaker authentication services.
YouTube videos showing side-by-side grading comparisons. Blog content targeting “how to grade used clothes,” “clothing condition guide,” and related SEO keywords.
Partner with reseller communities on r/Flipping, r/Streetwear, r/sneakermarket. Offer free grades to power sellers for reviews and testimonials.
Collaborate with reselling YouTubers and TikTok creators for sponsored grading demonstrations.
eBay seller groups, Poshmark ambassadors, Mercari power sellers.
First 1,000 users get 5 free Standard grades to build initial dataset and reviews.
Supabase setup, auth, user profiles, Stripe integration, core DB schema
Photo upload flow, image processing pipeline, AI grading integration, grade reports
Shareable certificates, user dashboard, submission history, analytics
UI polish, load testing, security audit, beta testing with 50 resellers
Public launch with marketing push, monitor and iterate
API, marketplace integrations, bulk grading, mobile app planning
GradeThread grades condition, not just authenticity; lower price point
GradeThread covers all clothing categories; condition not just auth
AI-powered for speed and consistency; standardized numerical grade
Comparable model applied to clothing; first-mover in apparel
Neutral third-party grade; standardized scale eliminates subjectivity

Launch with AI + human review on all Premium/Express; build dataset before reducing human involvement
Free grade offer for first 1,000 users; partner with reseller communities; focus on streetwear niche
Users game the system with misleading photos
Photo quality validation; flag inconsistent submissions; ban repeat offenders
Move fast to establish brand trust; build API partnerships that make platforms dependent on GradeThread
AI API cost per grade too high
Optimize prompts; batch processing; move to fine-tuned model in Phase 2 for lower inference cost
Tiered dispute SLA; improve AI accuracy to reduce disputes; automated dispute triage
The total number of items successfully graded per month. This directly correlates with revenue and dataset growth.

The core grading pipeline runs as a Supabase Edge Function triggered when a submission status changes to “processing”. The function fetches all submission images from storage, sends each image to the Vision API for per-image analysis, collects all per-image results into a composite prompt, sends the composite prompt for final grading, saves the grade report to the database, generates the certificate, updates submission status to “graded,” and sends the notification email. If confidence is below 0.75, the function flags the submission for human review instead of auto-publishing the grade.
Back condition, tag placement, rear defects
Closest area of wear or key feature
Cost efficiency ($18/mo vs $125/mo), full control over data, consistent with existing platform infrastructure, no vendor lock-in on scaling.
Type safety reduces bugs in grade calculation logic, fast development iteration, consistent developer experience across all Pearson Media platforms.
Handles per-grade payments, subscriptions, and usage-based API billing in one platform. Proven integration pattern from existing platforms.
Vision API (not custom model at launch):
Faster time-to-market, no training data required initially, leverages state-of-the-art vision capabilities. Custom model is Phase 2 after sufficient labeled data accumulates.
